extracted_information: The Web Content Accessibility Guidelines Evaluation Methodology (WCAG-EM) is a W3C-published process for evaluating websites for WCAG conformance. It outlines a five-step procedure for accessibility evaluations, considered best practices for audits.

features.name: WCAG-EM Web Accessibility Evaluation Process
features.description: A five-step procedure for accessibility evaluations to ensure consistent audits.
features.details: Each step includes recommendations, best practices, and guidance for evaluators, such as defining conformance targets (WCAG Level A, AA, AAA), identifying scope-affecting aspects (third-party content, mobile versions), and guidance for selecting structured and randomly selected page samples.

features.name: Best Practices for Accessibility Audits (General)
features.description: Recommendations for effective accessibility audits, beyond the WCAG-EM process itself.
criteria: Use both manual and automated tests
Include input from accessibility experts, developers, and people with disabilities
Provide resources for developing an Accessibility Statement to demonstrate conformance

features.name: Hybrid Testing Methodology (Mentioned by BoIA)
features.description: The Bureau of Internet Accessibility (BoIA) uses a four-point hybrid testing methodology.
features.details: Combines expert manual oversight with automated evaluations for WCAG conformance.
